While most conflicts with guerilla groups have ceased and ended peacefully, the only Latin American guerrilla movement that was both involved in the drug trade, and is no longer active, had the backing of another world government government. Many of the Latin American guerilla movements that were involved in drugs, and crime in general, are still active; while more political, less criminal movements tend to end.  Given that FARC appears to receive an inestimable amount of income from narcotics and other criminal enterprises, and that the Columbian government has opted to stop interfering with FARC's revenue source (http://www.breitbart.com/national-security/2016/04/20/colombia-rescinds-ban-pesticide-used-destroy-coca-crops/) there is no incentive for FARC to cease operations.

Mr. Obama was invited by FARC and Columbia  to work out a final peace agreement, which was one of the reasons he went to Cuba. to meet with them. The 'road map' was built over the past few years,  after 60 years of conflict, which included areas such as agriculture distribution, gender equality, economic assistance, post-conflict legal strategies, etc. The Obama administration also sold Columbia a number of modern weapon technologies to defeat FARC and ELN, the later group recently opening communication to join the peace agreement. 
The peace talks were delayed recently and it is unlikely that the agreement will become signed by the forecast. 
1. Mr. Santos popularity has fallen since the talks between his administration and FARC. Without strong numbers, his administration may not have the support of the government or the voters.
2. Demonstrations on the street by Right Wing groups who do not support the talks.
3.The Right Wing paramilitary, drug dealers, Conservative lawmakers both past and now, who do not support the talks, 
4. A vote by the Colombian people to accept the agreement. 
5. The FARC and ELN supporters want guarantees that their safety is not impeded upon by Conservative leaders with alliances to Right Wing death squads and other paramilitary or drug gangs, 
6. Pockets of resistance in FARC and ELN that do not want the talks to continue without further demands and rights.
7. The US senate has to agree upon a foreign aid package and, given the climate of the Senate, their record is to obfuscate and obstruct policies from the Obama administration.

With less than a month left until the end of this question, it appears that a final peace agreement will not be in place by that time. Examples of other government-rebel peace discussions that missed deadlines do not provide distinct trends for the length of negotiations after a missed deadline. Additionally, commentators on the FARC peace negotiations range in their belief that the sides will come to agreement, with some saying as early as June and others saying by the end of 2016. Additionally, it is not clear how often negotiations are being held at this time or what the announcement of the ELN talks will do to the FARC discussions. Despite that, the length of the negotiations thus far, and the outstanding issues including still getting a ceasefire agreement, provide little reassurance that they will be completed within the timeline of the question.

Santos would like to sign an agreement and have a chance to win the Nobel Peace Prize.  The leaders of the FARC do not want to give up their drug business and are used to living on the fringes of society.  There's a chance for an agreement but it's low probability.

With talks between the Colombian Government and ELN, the negotiation process on two fronts (with formidable enemies) it is reasonable to expect that the signing of a final peace agreement will be extended for some time.  It is unlikely that a negotiation strategy by the Colombian government will take two paths for each rebel/guerilla contestation.  The negotiations in fact will become more complicated and protracted in that the negotiations will need to take account for the demands & concessions of three parties.   Conflict between FACR and ELN has a long history along with their cooperation with the Colombian government over time.  A final negotiated solution would require a meeting of minds in compromise as well as a stabilized demobilization plan (which is currently the most difficult of all issues).  Demands by any side would have to renegotiated where agreement has previously reached.   The larger the size of the negotiation group, the larger the number of interactions are required to get to a signed peace accord.   May 2016 might still be too early to reach a settlement among the parties.

Pledges are for publicity and a line in the sand. A fitting  date would be the international workers day on May 1. So possible as far as the symbolism  but unlikely in reality. Those are my thoughts currently .

Dateline 3-23-16 Colombia’s government and left-wing FARC rebels missed the March 23 deadline for the signing of a peace agreement. While peace was not obtained, some progress has been made in the past six months. President Juan Manuel Santos and FARC leader “Timochenko” shook hands on September 23 to have a peace deal ready before March 23. By then, the parties that have been at war since 1964 had already agreed on victims, rural reform, political inclusion of the FARC and the rebels’ abandoning of the drug trade. However, with only “End of Conflict” left on the agenda, the issues of establishing a permanent bilateral ceasefire and the demobilization of the left-wing guerrillas became major stumbling blocks that effectively made Santos and Timochenko break their promise to the Colombian people. http://colombiareports.com/colombia-peace-talks-miss-deadline-not-without-progress/

A final peace deal is starting to look as though it will eventually be in reach, unfortunately I do not believe such negotiations can be finalized in such a short period of time. Peace will not be finalized if the issue of amnesty and extradition remains open. It will take a while for the Colombian Congress to draft legislation that would legalize such measures within the transitional courts. It should be noted that the Santos Government would have simple majority support if it decides to push for amnesty and non-extradition and a simple majority is all that is required to pass such legislation. http://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/articles/18172/santos-stumbles-in-homestretch-of-colombia-farc-peace-talks " . . . the reality on the ground suggests that reaching a permanent agreement could be more difficult now than it appeared only a few months ago. . . . There is little doubt that the president and FARC will ultimately deliver some type of document, such as a permanent cease-fire, to sign by the agreed date, if only to save face and reassure the population that the process is still on track. But it seems extremely unlikely that the March 23 date will bring the more conclusive deal that was originally intended. "Much has transpired since the heady days early last month when Santos was being discussed as a potential Nobel Peace Prize winner and President Barack Obama warmly welcomed his “good friend, President Santos,” and Santos’ wife to the White House. The latest poll by Gallup Colombia, taken during the final 10 days of February, shows a stunning collapse in support for Santos and his peace plan. Only 24 percent approve of the Colombian president’s performance in office. Support for the peace process is also in trouble, with just 37 percent saying they believe the peace process is on the right track.  "Colombians are feeling so ambivalent about what they are witnessing that only 30 percent say they will definitely vote in the referendum to ratify an eventual peace deal. Among those, a slim majority of 53 percent say they will vote in favor of the accord. . . .  Assuming an agreement is reached, which remains the likely outcome, it is quite possible that the referendum campaign will motivate more Colombians to go to the polls. "Until then, however, the path forward for Santos has become doggedly complicated.  "FARC negotiators understand that Santos, who has staked his presidency on ending the half-century-old war, will not let the peace process collapse. They are leveraging that psychological advantage to demand compromises that Santos may approve, but which the Colombian people reject. "Santos, who has staked his presidency on ending the half-century-old war, will not let the peace process collapse.
It all adds up to a dilemma for Santos. In order to get FARC to sign a deal, he is under pressure to offer concessions that could doom the referendum. Making matters worse, his popularity, setting aside the peace process, is taking a beating from a host of other factors . . .  " . . .  a video recorded in late February showed FARC leaders flanked by machine-gun-toting guerrillas, in violation of the terms of the agreement. The video went viral, and the state prosecutor launched an investigation of the minister of defense and top military officials to determine whether they withdrew Colombian forces from the area, leaving the population under FARC control during the visit. To many Colombians, it was a sign of how FARC is outplaying the government and cannot be trusted. "The issue of what will happen to FARC’s weapons is one of the top sources of concern. Guerrilla negotiators are playing semantic games, saying they will not hand over their weapons, but only set them aside. And they are demanding to decide who will stockpile them. One FARC negotiator has even suggested that the military, too, ought to disarm. Colombians are also troubled by demands from the guerrillas to choose the makeup of the tribunals that will judge them, along with reports that any FARC members that are eventually sanctioned will be allowed to run for office even while serving their punishments. Those punishments are expected, per earlier agreements, to be rather mild, a point that angers Colombians.  "Former President Alvaro Uribe, now in Congress, remains the top critic of the deal and the “impunity” he maintains it will produce despite the grave crimes committed by FARC members. . . . "But Santos also has a full plate of problems that could weigh on his efforts to persuade Colombians to support a deal. The collapse of oil prices has slashed government revenues and dealt a blow to the currency, which has lost half its value, reducing purchasing power and stoking inflation. The central bank is hiking rates to tamp down inflation, adding to the pressure on economic growth. The economy, which had been growing at a strong clip, is slowing noticeably. The president just announced a cut in government spending, even as the unemployment rate has climbed.In the meantime, a severe drought, along with mismanagement, has depleted hydroelectric production. Water and electricity shortages are adding to popular irritation with the government. And the proliferation of corruption scandals in the administration is hurting the president. Although he has not been directly linked to the cases, they are likely turning him into a less credible advocate for his policies, including the peace process. When the minister of mines and energy resigned this week, Santos had to clarify that it was because of the energy crisis, not because of corruption schemes to which the minister has been linked. Other Cabinet members under investigation include the ministers of the interior, health, housing and defense.  "It all adds to a complicated picture for a president who remains determined to reach a final peace agreement, and a population that wants peace but is skeptical that this process will produce a lasting version of it.

http://www.as-coa.org/articles/update-colombias-do-list-ahead-peace-deadline  " . . .  with several complicated points still unresolved, both sides are backing off the March 23 itself, albeit still committed to signing an agreement in 2016. 
. . . 
"This week, the Colombian Congress approved a law that grants the government the power to create demobilization zones, areas in which the country’s security forces won’t be allowed to arrest FARC members even if there is a warrant out on the guerillas. The government’s idea is that, if an agreement is reached, guerrilla members will congregate in these zones to safely turn in their weapons. But some are concerned the FARC won’t hold up its end of this portion of the deal. . . . The debate in Congress on demobilization zones has prompted criticism from the opposition, which wants to avoid a repeat of the El Caguán incident in the early 2000s. In that case, then-President Andrés Pastrana cleared security forces from 16,200 square miles in southern Colombia to get FARC leaders to agree to peace talks there, but the rebels took the opportunity to regroup. 
. . . .
"Negotiators in Havana will also have to put mechanisms in place to ensure that guerillas will be reintegrated into civilian life. Both sides have diverging reasons for achieving this goal. The FARC wants to be sure that their unarmed members won’t become victims of targeted killings, as other leftist groups have been in the past upon turning in their weapons. . . .  "Meanwhile, the government is also interested in guaranteeing that demobilized guerrilla members won’t join the loosely organized criminal gangs, known as Bacrim, which would become the country’s largest illegal armed group once the FARC disarm. Specifically to guard against this, President Juan Manuel Santos said that any demobilized FARC member who commits a new crime will be subject to extradition to the United States, something fighters who disarm under the agreement won’t face.   "The last point to be agreed upon, which involves financing, monitoring, verification, and implementation of the peace agenda and post-conflict efforts, might prove to be the thorniest. The peace agreement would create a bureaucratic apparatus of commissions and special courts for transitional justice and truth commissions, as well as requiring spending on victim reparations and infrastructure building. But the country currently is facing financial pains . . .  Obama recently pledged to ask U.S. Congress to increase the amount to $450 million for 2017. But . . .  Bank of America estimated the total cost for 10 years of post-conflict efforts to be about $16.8 billion, or 1 percent of GDP per year. The Colombian Congress wants to budget even more. Roy Barreras, the leader of the governing Party of the U, calculated the cost for 10 years at $28.1 billion and asked for 2 percent of the country’s GDP to be destined to cover post-conflict costs. If the peace agreement is signed, the Colombian Congress will then have to vote and approve this new budget and post-conflict line item. "What’s more, it remains undecided how transitional justice—the parallel legal system that will try crimes connected to the Colombian conflict—will work, and Santos has so far issued only partial explanations. This means that the number of special judges is still to be determined and costs can change, but also that there is plenty to discuss when it comes to the minutiae of these justice mechanism. It also remains to be seen whether the agreement would satisfy international legal requirements Colombia is party to, or if it would be granting impunity to convicted criminals, as some legal experts claim.   "The last point of negotiations deals with the means by which Colombians can accept or reject an agreement signed by the government and the FARC in Havana. Congress already approved the final text of the negotiations to be put before voters through a plebiscite, scheduled for no later than four months after the final signature of the peace agreement, and which must receive support of 13 percent of Colombia’s electorate, or 4.4 million votes in the affirmative. But the FARC leaders believe this is a one-sided solution, as they will not have a say on the text of the question put to voters. Instead, the FARC have been pushing for a constituent assembly, which the government strongly opposes because each negotiating point would have to be approved—and debated—one by one. As chief negotiator Humberto de La Calle said, “[A constituent assembly] would not be an end to dialogue. On the contrary, it’d start the process all over again.” "In February, Santos said that if the deadline is not met, “Colombians will understand that the FARC is not ready for peace.” But now both sides seem to be backing off the March 23 date. The group’s lead negotiator Iván Márquez hinted that they are willing to continue the talks until later this year. On March 3, Foreign Minister María Ángela Holguín said that “something will be signed on March 23,” opening up the possibility that only a partial agreement is reached that day. Then on March 9, Santos himself said, "I am not going to sign a bad agreement just to meet a deadline...If a good deal has not been reached by March 23, I will tell the other side of the table, 'Let's set another date.'" He added, "I hope we can sign. Negotiators are in the final stretch."
~~~~~~~

Colombia’s FARC rebel leadership confirmed they are ready to reach a peace deal as soon as possible, while the government reiterated that 2016 is the year to end war as the final phase of end-of-conflict negotiations between the two sides of the over 50 year armed internal conflict restarted in Havana, Cuba, on Wednesday after a controversy briefly stalled the talks. “Our commitment and political decision is to continue moving forward with our all our determination toward the signing of a final agreement,” chief FARC negotiator Ivan Marquez said to media. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia has said its movement is “fully prepared” to agree to a “timetable and roadmap” to reach a final peace deal between the two sides “without delay.” The peace negotiations had set a self-imposed deadline of March 23 to sign a peace accord in Havana to bring an end to the over three-year peace process and five-decade conflict, but various setbacks have made meeting the proposed date increasingly unlikely. The government, on the other hand, has not changed its tune that 2016 is the year of peace heralded by Colombian President Juan Manuel Santos at the New Year, but it seems that officials may no longer see March as the month for peace in the South American country. “This is an important year for the history of Colombia,” Foreign Minister Maria Angela Holguin said during an address to the U.N. Human Rights Council on Wednesday, adding that the peace process in Havana has reached its final stages. “We expect that 2016 will mark the end of the over 50 year armed conflict, the largest in the western hemisphere.” Both Holguin and Marquez acknowledged that the peace process has achieved major developments and historic agreements have been met. However, challenges still remain as the negotiators work through the final steps. “Experience at the (negotiating) table has showed that when acts are done without taking the counterpart into consideration, the negotiation falls into the swamp and impedes progress,” said Marquez, adding that achieving a bilateral cease-fire, ending paramilitary activity, and ensuring the FARC’s transformation into a legal political movement remain key obstacles to be overcome. IN DEPTH: The Colombian Peace Process Explained On the government side, efforts to remove landmines are seen as crucial priority in ensuring stable and lasting peace, Holguin said. Last May, both sides of the conflict agreed to launch a preliminary demining initiative after the country saw more than 11,000 people injured or killed over the last 15 years. The peace process has got back underway with full force after a government uproar over a visit by Marquez and other FARC leaders to the town of El Conejo earlier this month where photos showed armed rebels were in the vicinity of the leaders FARC negotiator Ivan Marquez visits El Conejo, Feb. 18, 2016. The government accused the negotiators of breaking the rules of camp visits and banned them from making such trips. The FARC accused the country’s right wing of creating an “unwarranted controversy” over the visit. Cuba and Norway, the two guarantor countries supporting the peace process, had to step in to smooth over the situation after the controversy launched an impasse at the negotiating table. Both sides also agreed to a protocol for FARC tours to communicate peace process progress. While it seems unlikely the two sides of the conflict will meet the self-imposed deadline of having a final peace agreement March 23, FARC and government negotiators agree that peace is near.

I share @Rucas_1972  concerns and peace agreements are always tricky. They tend to fail way more often than they succeed, even if they get signed.
However, I am optimistic. The government may indeed get a better deal in the future (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/144211), but on the other hand this depends on wether the FARC-negotiators would be able to maintain their influence inside FARC, if these talks fail right now. The gov. is still facing the left-wing ELN and strong right-wing rebelgroups and needs it resources for them. Therefore that approach may be too risky. Furthermore, Santos political 'destiny' seems to be pretty much bound to the conclusion of a peace deal by now. He is facing a strong opposition and harsh criticism for these talks. I doubt he will survive a failure politically. The FARC know that too, of course. So in fact, both sides want that deal. UN support is already agreed upon (which is a huge milestone), and US aid-money will start to flow in, once the deal got signed and approved. All in all, there are strong incentives for the conclusion of a deal. The only things that worry me, are the US-Terrorlist and the timeframe. Naturally, both parties will continue to try to push the agreement in a better direction for themselves. They may overstep at some point and might then need time to reconsider their positions. There are no lurking sanctions in place, that may force the negotiators to finish the talks in the agreed-upon timeframe (Contrary to the recent peace deal in South Sudan, where IGAD+ succesfully threatened to sanction both negotiating parties. However, this still did not lead to an actual implemention of the deal.) Regarding the US-Terrorlist: The FARC will not be taken down until they signed the treaty, got rid of all their arms and until it got acknowledged by the US, that they no longer pose a threat. This may take 1-3 years even if everything is going great. But the fact that Santos publicly stated that he is unhappy with that procedure I think makes his commitment to the talks clear. The FARC may have hoped for the US to be less resistant, however that's the standard procedure by the US as far as I know and the FARC might have anticipated that outcome beforehand anyway. I am not sure WHO exactly is on that list and/or who would be really threatened by a peace deal (and the loss of fighters/weapons) inside FARC. And I doubt that the FARC are sure themselves. Downside: I am also not sure wether the negotiators returned to Cuba yet:

This is a really tough one! Well looking at the history of peace talks between FARC and the Government  in Colombia in the last 30 years (here: http://colombiareports.com/peace-talks-colombia-farc-eln/ ), I  see that they usually don't last more than 3 years and then fail. Not a good omen.  That indicates that peace talks are more often than not a PR trick between the parts, some kind of truce to consolidate power and show a good face, Because let's face it: if you are in good faith, you don't need 3 years to reach an agreement. Right? (or wrong? :-) :-) ) This last round has been going on for 4 years so... and there is a deadline on the 23 March (source:  http://www.bignewsnetwork.com/news/241541899/colombian-president-rejects-farc-peace-negotiation-extension).  I don't feel confident in an agreement anytime soon. As a base probability I would give it no more than 10% So, to improve my confidence, I look for what may be different this time. And this time something is different: FARC, usually supported by the Venezuelan Bolivarian Revolution, is loosing its main support base as Socialists are starting to lose power in Venzuela. On the other hand, the government is really making a dent on FARC's military capacity .  Those two factors are putting pressure on FARC for an agreement but are an incentive to the Government to postpone an agreement as they might get better conditions later on when FARC is weaker than now.  So, how does that leave me? Well... I will give 20% for Yes but I really think it is less.  Help is really appreciated on this one as this is the most difficult forecast I came across in GJO (but I am newbie, anyway :-)  :-) )

When the agreement was made in mid January, the Colombian government and FARC, agreed on an international component to help coordinate, mediate, settle disputes, make recommendations and present reports.   On January 25, The UN Security Council approved "a political mission to monitor the implementation of a peace deal between the Colombian government and the rebel Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC)," following the request made by the parties.  This political mission was set to last 12 months.  And its creation is supposed to be seen as a strong signal that a MARCH 23 DEADLINE TO REACH THE FINAL AGREEMENT COULD BE WITHIN REACH.  This peace process has been in the making for four years.  January's announcement was seen, in Latin America, as a big victory.  The negotiations started in 2012 and came in four stages:   1) The first stage which was the phase of secret meetings and exploratory talks that lasted 6 months.  
2) The second which focused on making concrete agreement plans and discussions regarding policies for agricultural development; the political participation that members of FARC would have in government once disarmament happens; drug trafficking control policy, and reparations to the victims of the conflict (FARC and government victims).   
3) A third stage which covered ratification of the agreement and signatures
4) And a fourth, which is the implementation of the agreement.   The agreement is at the final stretch - hopefully - BUT MARCH 23 is fast approaching and just this week, the government of Colombia stopped FARC leaders visit to the country which they said was to brief fighters on the peace talks.   The government claimed FARC HAD VIOLATED THE TERMS OF THE AGREEMENT because FARC leaders Ivan Marquez, Jesus Santrich and Joaquin Gomez, who had traveled from Havana, Cuba, had "met with local residents and participated in public events with armed fighters despite restrictions on such activities."  "On instruction of the president, pedagogical visits by FARC delegates to their encampments to explain the accords are suspended," 
"A fundamental rule of the agreement was that they do not make politics with arms and so this is an unacceptable violation." Doesn't seem like this violation of the agreement is so egregious that the progress made will be undone but it may be an indicator of how seriously or not the parts are taking the terms.    IF THE MARCH 23 DEADLINE IS MISSED, THEN THAT COULD BE A SET BACK FOR THE ACCORD.  LET'S KEEP AN EYE ON THAT DATE. It looks like FARC really wants this. Its most strenuous objection to the negotiations so far seems to be the intention of Pres. Santos to call a referendum. But my understanding is that this will be a non-binding plebescite. It seems that Santos is often criticized for strong-arming whatever he wants through the legislature, so the plebiscite is a gesture to public opinion. The other issue is the United States' list of terrorist organizations and threats to extradite about 50 FARC members wanted on drug trafficking charges. Santos has prevented extradition in the past, but it's unclear if he will be able to get a blanket commitment from the US not to pursue it. US has said that FARC will not be removed from terrorist list until after they give up arms, so the order in which things need to be done may be an obstacle. Even so, if Santos can get some promises from the US, and the FARC negotiators trust him, there could be an agreement before May.

President Juan Manuel Santos and Las Farc leadership did not reach common ground on the path-to-peace. The government intends to consult the public on the path-to-peace terms via a referendum (plebiscito refrendatorio), and Las Farc leadership argues that this is not part of the cease-fire agreement and is unconstitutional. So, the government will take some time to delineate the agreeement (and have it reviewed by judicial authorities), align it with las Farc leadership, organise and perform the referendum, make results public and (in case las Farc does not raise any complaints) proceed with the transitional program. That is a lot of work to get done in a 2.5 months time window. Additionally, I sense a certain increase in hostility in the way President Juan Manuel Santos communicates his positions about Farc (example: on Twitter: "Lo que se firme en La Habana lo someteré a plebiscito, les guste o no a las Farc" --- sounds rude for a native listener/reader). In another episode, in last December, President Juan Manuel Santos said that it is important to strengthen the military in order to reach and keep permanent peace, during a ceremony in la Escuela Militar de Cadetes, one of the most relevant military academies in Colombia. In South America, this message sounds strange because the military directly lead or sponsored many of the dictatorships regimes that doomed the region until very recently, so empowering the military sounds a bit like despair to me. http://caracol.com.co/radio/2016/02/09/nacional/1455033660_899781.html

The Colombian Peace talks are beset with significant substantive problems regarding the integration of its paramilitary force, the question of its ownership and share of 60% of cocaine production and distribution (a significant financial asset that FARC is unlikely to give up), and previously stalled negotiations over the last 5 years.   Leading negotiators for FARC have indicated publicly in Cuba during its recent negotiations with the Colombian ruling government that its (government) of a March deadline to complete all outstanding issues in the negotiations is naive, unreasonable and illusive.   A significant component yet to negotiated is the creating and establishment (which all agree would take at least a decade or more) of a sustainable economy in the FARC controlled territory among the landless, peasants and other classes.  Its illusive tasks are made difficult in that it needs to find an economy that can sustain and surpass the economic benefits of a narcoterrorist economy (cocaine).  With the additional two month requirement established by this question (beyond March) does not make an agreement more possible;  beside agreement substantively differs from signing an agreement.  The Colombian government is still beset with problems of regarding the ELN (a major guerilla organization) with whom it has no history of negotiations.   This dispels the fantasy that ongoing conflict interactions between it and the government, it and FARC could present significantly more dangers to a peace process, were it to be achieved.  So the question remains, given the status quo, or a move to FARC agreement and military integration, and the creation of an economy that is able to sustain a large population of FARC supporters and members in its territory, will peace move Colombia into an abyss much more aggressive than it current status.  At this posting, escalation in military conflict continues between the government and the ELN. Given these hurdles, my assessment is that a signed agreement will not be achieve despite the United State's commitment to providing a significant aid package (which it has been doing for year given the underdetermined problems of narcoterrorism) to provide incentives to move the agreement along as well as bring FARC into the fold and create a sustainable economy that will significantly soften Marxist grievances and suffering.

Government has incentives to comply with the agreed date (March 23th). However, given the nature of the conflict and the difficulties on agreeing, and the usual tendency to not comply with deadlines by Latin American governments, I would say that it is unlikely they sign the agreement by this date. 
In addition, FARC leaders have said that, in their view, "it is almost impossible" to comply with the due date due to important holes in the current negotiations. Further, FARC leaders don't care much about deadlines and, even though this might increase their negotiating power, I'm not sure to what extent the Colombian government is ready to grant them at the expense of complying with deadlines. 
I believe chances are good the agreement will be signed this year, so I'm considering the agreement could be signed any day of 2016.

The parties set a March 23 deadline, and while one side (FARC) essentially called that “naïve,” resolution by the forecasting question (May 1) seems promising following a Santos visit to Washington, Obama’s commitment of increase funding (albeit in fiscal year 2017, which does not being until October 1), the release of prisoners by Santos, and a UNSC verification/monitoring commitment, which both sides requested. However, I think a survey of history would suggest that an agreement of this magnitude slips even further. I tried to find some analysis on analogous situations (e.g., Northern Ireland), but didn’t discover. Therefore, I don’t have data to evaluate my hypothesis, but I’m willing to let it inform my forecast nonetheless. I think a peace agreement will be reached sometime this year, but given the comments and reactions since December, I think this is likely to go past May 1. Deadlines can harden positions as much as they can encourage resolution, and I think typically deadlines encourage resolution when a powerful third party is establishing them. There are a number of interested external parties, the US foremost among them, but I don't know if the Obama Administration has the bandwidth to midwife this peace agreement by May 1.

As of Oct 2015, 46% of Columbians were optimistic that the peace talks would succeed. At that time, both parties agreed on over 80% of the peace terms. The largest remaining issues were (1) how peace would be monitored/guaranteed, (2) how to ensure that FARC supporters would not be targeted by paramilitary groups after the agreement, (3) how the rebel leaders would be punished for their actions. The following issues still remain undecided:
1) How restrictive will "restriction of liberty" be? (maximum security vs. country club jail vs. probation?)
2) How much responsibility should the leaders have
3) Will amnesty result in mass-prisoner releases
4) How will narco-trafficking be treated (eligible for amnesty)?
5) Will there be financial restitution?
6) Can FARC leaders seek political office while under "restriction of liberty"
7) How will tribunal judges be chosen?
8) How will civilian supporters of paramilitary groups be dealt with (punished or not?)
9) Will government officials be punished for targeting pro-FARC supporters ("false positives") On 1/19/16, both parties agreed to a tripartite monitoring committee consisting of FARC, government, and international representation (UN) for the peace process. In some ways, this reminds me of the War Crimes Tribunals of WW2 or Serbia/former Yugoslavia. Most likely, not all guilty parties will be arrested, convicted, or receive "fair" sentences, but in the interests of peace, Columbia will most likely move forward.

While 23 March isn't likely, sometime before 1 May is better than 50/50. 3-Feb-2016: LatinOne: Negotiations, which are being held in Cuba, have reached agreements on land reform, combating illegal drug trafficking, guerrilla participation in politics, transitional justice, efforts to search for missing persons, and remove land mines, Reuters listed. A United Nations mission will oversee rebel disarmament once a deal is signed. http://www.latinone.com/articles/31752/20160201/colombia-s-farc-rebels-expected-hold-political-positions-peace-deal.htm 1-Feb-2016: The negotiations being conducted in Havana, Cuba have a five point agenda: (1) land reform, (2) political participation of demobilized FARC, (3) drug trafficking, (4) victims’ rights and reparations, and (5) disarmament of the rebels and implementation of the peace deal. As stated earlier, the two sides reached partial agreements on four of the five points: land reform, political participation, drug trafficking, and transitional justice.  Pending issues include disarmament and how the final agreement will be approved, verified, and implemented.  The FARC has agreed to give up its weapons within 60 days after the final accord is signed. However, the government asserts that FARC members should surrender their weapons to the government, so they can never be used again. The FARC seeks to "set aside" their weapons, meaning the group will store its own arms with the implication that the FARC could at some point return to armed struggle. This remains an unresolved issue. 
Since the negotiations began, President Santos has promised that the Colombian people would approve the final peace agreement in some type of referendum. In December, the Colombian Congress approved legislation to seek ratification of a peace deal through a plebiscite, a one-day vote requiring only 13% of the electoral census to achieve ratification.
